subject: RE: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.
msgSnippet: Raffie and Andrew, When a test suite fails I would like to have clear information about what is going wrong. Having multiple assertion failures for a single
messageBody:
Raffie and Andrew,

When a test suite fails I would like to have clear information about what is
going wrong. Having multiple assertion failures for a single test case would
help with this. However, it would complicate the testing framework. As a
test writer, you have the option of dividing your tests finer to give you
more information. While some people go so far as to say that tests *should*
have one assertion each, I generally have one or two assertions per test,
with a fair number of tests with 4, 5, or 6 assertions (I wonder if this is
fat tail distribution? I don't have enough data to be confident. Any
master's students out there who need a thesis topic?)

In all the years I have done testing frameworks this way, I've never missed
seeing multiple failures from a single test case. Thinking back to my
debugging experience, I think that 90%+ of the time when an assertion fails,
a single change gets the whole test running. Can you tell me more about the
situation in which you wanted to see multiple assertion failures for a
singlde test?

Take care,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Andrew McDonagh
> Sent: Monday, August 22, 2005 4:13 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.
>
> raffadub wrote:
>
> >Assuming there is a test function with several assertions; if one
> >failes the assertions past it are not executed. Is there a way to get
> >around this issue? More specifically; is it possible to execute all
> >assertions in a test function despite some have failed.
> >
> >I attempted using JFunc, but it is slightly incomplete. Other than
> >this extension, I have had little luck finding anything else.
> >
> >Cheers!
> >-Raffie-
> >
> >
> >
> >
>
> If your test is failing why do you care whether any remaining
> assertions
> haven't been run?
>
> Why can't you fix the code to make it pass the failing
> assertion, then
> see if the remaining assertions pass or not.
>
> Aside from this, having multiple assertions within a single test is
> actually the problem - you want to be aiming for one
> assertion per test,
> not multiple.
>
> HTH
>
>
> Andrew
